title: Vascular Dementia
scope: ** Diagnosis using NINDS-AIREN and DSM-5 criteria, neuroimaging evaluation for strategic infarcts and white matter disease, vascular risk factor modification, secondary stroke prevention, cholinesterase inhibitors for cognitive symptoms, and management of post-stroke depression, apathy, and behavioral symptoms. Primarily outpatient-focused with coverage for ED and hospital presentations.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Metabolic causes of confusion; renal function for medication dosing
Hypothyroidism is reversible cause of cognitive impairment
Deficiency causes reversible cognitive decline and may worsen vascular dementia
Deficiency contributes to hyperhomocysteinemia and cognitive impairment
Diabetes is major vascular risk factor; assess chronic glucose control
Assess LDL for secondary stroke prevention; target <70 mg/dL
UTI common cause of acute confusion in elderly
Baseline coagulation; assess if on anticoagulation

Extended Workup.rationale: Elevated levels increase stroke risk and contribute to vascular dementia
Independent cardiovascular risk marker; elevated increases stroke risk
Inflammatory marker; elevated predicts vascular events
Deficiency associated with cognitive decline and vascular disease
Neurosyphilis is treatable cause of dementia
HIV-associated neurocognitive disorder if risk factors
Hepatic encephalopathy; nutritional status; statin safety
Heart failure; atrial fibrillation risk assessment
Elevated associated with increased stroke and dementia risk

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin; young-onset vascular disease
Suspected CNS vasculitis causing multi-infarct state
Suspected CADASIL (family history, migraine, early WM disease)

Lumbar Puncture.target: Normal Aβ42 in pure VaD; low suggests mixed AD/VaD

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Elevated in AD; can help distinguish VaD from AD
Lumbar Puncture.target: Normal or mildly elevated in pure VaD; high p-tau suggests AD

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Non-specific marker of neuronal damage; elevated in vascular injury

Essential/First-line.target: Strategic infarcts (thalamus, basal ganglia, angular gyrus); confluent WMH (Fazekas ≥2); lacunar infarcts
Rule out hemorrhage, mass, hydrocephalus; may show old infarcts, leukoaraiosis
Intracranial and extracranial atherosclerosis; assess for stenosis >50%
Assess for atrial fibrillation, LVH, prior MI
LV function; valvular disease; intracardiac thrombus

Extended.target: Quantify WM lesion volume; global and regional atrophy

Extended.timing: Differentiate VaD from AD; atypical cases
Distinguish pure VaD from mixed AD/VaD
Extended.target: Negative suggests pure VaD; positive suggests mixed pathology

Extended.timing: Sleep apnea is vascular risk factor; assess for OSA

Rare/Specialized.timing: Suspected CNS vasculitis or reversible vasoconstriction
Rare/Specialized.target: No vessel wall enhancement or thickening

Rare/Specialized.timing: Cryptogenic strokes; suspected aortic arch atheroma or PFO

doseOptions.orderSentence: Treat reversible causes Per specific cause Various

dosing.instructions: Correct hyponatremia slowly, treat UTI, replace B12, treat hypothyroidism
dosing.orderSentence: Treat reversible causes Per specific cause Various

dosing.instructions: 500 mg IV TID x 3 days if Wernicke suspected; then 100 mg PO daily maintenance

Acute/Emergent.indication: Immediate antiplatelet therapy for secondary stroke prevention

dosing.instructions: 325 mg loading dose if no recent stroke, then 81 mg daily ongoing

doseOptions.orderSentence: Blood pressure management (acute) Per protocol Various

dosing.instructions: Do NOT lower BP aggressively unless >220/120 or end-organ damage; permissive hypertension first 24-48h of stroke
dosing.orderSentence: Blood pressure management (acute) Per protocol Various

Vascular Risk Factor Modification (Secon.indication: High-intensity statin for secondary stroke prevention; LDL target <70

dosing.instructions: Start 40-80 mg daily; target LDL <70 mg/dL; 80 mg preferred for established vascular disease

Vascular Risk Factor Modification (Secon.monitoring: LFTs at baseline, 6-12 weeks, then annually; myalgias

Vascular Risk Factor Modification (Secon.indication: Alternative high-intensity statin; may be better tolerated

dosing.instructions: Start 20 mg daily; max 40 mg; potent LDL lowering

Vascular Risk Factor Modification (Secon.contraindications: Active liver disease; pregnancy; Asian dose adjustment (10 mg start)

Vascular Risk Factor Modification (Secon.indication: Lifelong antiplatelet for secondary stroke prevention

dosing.instructions: 81 mg daily indefinitely for non-cardioembolic vascular dementia

Vascular Risk Factor Modification (Secon.indication: Alternative to aspirin if aspirin-intolerant; or after DAPT period

dosing.instructions: 75 mg daily; may use instead of aspirin if intolerant

Vascular Risk Factor Modification (Secon.indication: Blood pressure control; target <130/80 for secondary prevention

dosing.instructions: Start 5-10 mg daily; titrate to goal BP <130/80; max 40 mg daily

Vascular Risk Factor Modification (Secon.contraindications: Angioedema history; pregnancy; bilateral RAS; hyperkalemia

Vascular Risk Factor Modification (Secon.indication: BP control; add-on or alternative antihypertensive

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg daily; may increase to 10 mg daily

Vascular Risk Factor Modification (Secon.indication: Thiazide-like diuretic for BP control; effective for stroke prevention

dosing.instructions: Start 12.5 mg daily; may increase to 25 mg daily

Vascular Risk Factor Modification (Secon.indication: First-line for type 2 diabetes if eGFR >30

dosing.instructions: Start 500 mg daily with meal; titrate by 500 mg weekly; max 2000-2550 mg/day in divided doses

Vascular Risk Factor Modification (Secon.monitoring: eGFR; B12 annually; lactic acidosis symptoms

Vascular Risk Factor Modification (Secon.indication: SGLT2 inhibitor for diabetes with cardiovascular benefit

dosing.instructions: Start 10 mg daily; may increase to 25 mg; cardiovascular mortality benefit

Vascular Risk Factor Modification (Secon.indication: Add-on for LDL not at goal on statin

dosing.instructions: 10 mg daily with or without food
5 mg BID (2.5 mg BID if ≥2 of: age ≥80, weight ≤60 kg, Cr ≥1.5)
20 mg daily with dinner (15 mg if CrCl 15-50)

Vascular Risk Factor Modification (Secon.indication: Mechanical valve; select hypercoagulable states; AF if DOACs contraindicated

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg daily; adjust to INR 2-3

Vascular Risk Factor Modification (Secon.contraindications: Active bleeding; frequent falls; poor adherence

Cholinesterase Inhibitors (Cognitive Enh.indication: Vascular dementia cognitive symptoms; modest but measurable benefit

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg qHS x 4-6 weeks; if tolerated, increase to 10 mg qHS; benefit smaller than in AD

Cholinesterase Inhibitors (Cognitive Enh.contraindications: Sick sinus syndrome; second/third degree heart block without pacemaker; active GI bleeding
Cholinesterase Inhibitors (Cognitive Enh.monitoring: Heart rate; GI symptoms (nausea, diarrhea); vivid dreams

Cholinesterase Inhibitors (Cognitive Enh.indication: Vascular dementia; executive dysfunction; may help mixed AD/VaD

dosing.instructions: Start 1.5 mg BID with meals; increase by 1.5 mg BID every 2 weeks; target 6 mg BID

Cholinesterase Inhibitors (Cognitive Enh.indication: Vascular dementia; better GI tolerability than oral

dosing.instructions: Start 4.6 mg/24hr patch; increase every 4 weeks; target 9.5-13.3 mg/24hr

Cholinesterase Inhibitors (Cognitive Enh.indication: Vascular dementia; dual mechanism may benefit executive function

dosing.instructions: Start 4 mg BID with meals x 4 weeks; increase to 8 mg BID x 4 weeks; target 8-12 mg BID

Cholinesterase Inhibitors (Cognitive Enh.contraindications: Sick sinus; severe renal impairment (CrCl <9); severe hepatic impairment

Cholinesterase Inhibitors (Cognitive Enh.indication: Moderate-severe vascular dementia; add to cholinesterase inhibitor

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg daily x 1 week; increase by 5 mg/week: 5 mg BID, then 5/10 mg, then 10 mg BID

Cholinesterase Inhibitors (Cognitive Enh.contraindications: Severe renal impairment (reduce dose if CrCl 5-29: max 5 mg BID)

dosing.instructions: Start 25 mg daily; increase by 25 mg every 1-2 weeks; typical 50-100 mg daily; max 200 mg

Post-Stroke Depression and Apathy.monitoring: GI upset initially; bleeding risk with anticoagulants; sexual dysfunction

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg daily in elderly; increase to 10 mg after 1 week; max 20 mg (10 mg if >65y)

Post-Stroke Depression and Apathy.monitoring: QTc if cardiac risk; GI symptoms

dosing.instructions: Start 10 mg daily; max 20 mg in elderly due to QT prolongation risk

Post-Stroke Depression and Apathy.monitoring: ECG at baseline if cardiac risk; QTc monitoring

Post-Stroke Depression and Apathy.indication: Depression with poor appetite, weight loss, and insomnia

dosing.instructions: Start 7.5-15 mg qHS; may increase to 30-45 mg qHS; lower doses more sedating

Post-Stroke Depression and Apathy.indication: Depression with fatigue and apathy; no sexual side effects; avoid if seizure risk

dosing.instructions: Start 100 mg SR daily or 150 mg XL daily; may increase after 3 days; max 400 mg/day

Post-Stroke Depression and Apathy.contraindications: Seizure disorder; anorexia/bulimia; abrupt alcohol/benzo withdrawal

Post-Stroke Depression and Apathy.indication: Apathy refractory to antidepressants; psychomotor retardation

dosing.instructions: Start 2.5-5 mg BID (morning and noon); titrate by 2.5-5 mg every 3-5 days; max 30 mg/day

Post-Stroke Depression and Apathy.contraindications: Severe hypertension; cardiac arrhythmias; hyperthyroidism; glaucoma

dosing.instructions: Start 100 mg each morning; may increase to 200 mg daily
Start 25-50 mg qHS; titrate by 25-50 mg every 3-5 days; typical 50-150 mg qHS

Behavioral and Psychological Symptoms of.indication: Sleep disturbance; circadian rhythm dysfunction; sundowning

dosing.instructions: Start 3 mg qHS, 30 min before bed; may increase to 6 mg if needed

Behavioral and Psychological Symptoms of.indication: Severe agitation/psychosis when non-pharmacologic interventions fail

dosing.instructions: Start 12.5-25 mg qHS; titrate slowly; keep dose as low as possible

Behavioral and Psychological Symptoms of.contraindications: Black box: increased mortality and stroke in dementia; Parkinson's (less risk than others)

dosing.instructions: Start 0.25 mg BID; increase by 0.25 mg BID weekly; max 1 mg BID; limit to 6-12 weeks

Behavioral and Psychological Symptoms of.contraindications: Black box: increased mortality and CVA in dementia
Behavioral and Psychological Symptoms of.monitoring: EPS, metabolic effects, stroke risk, prolactin

Behavioral and Psychological Symptoms of.indication: Acute severe agitation in delirium-crisis only (avoid chronic use)

dosing.instructions: 0.5-2 mg IM/IV q4-6h PRN; short-term acute use only; avoid chronic use in dementia
Start 100 mg BID; titrate to 200-400 mg BID based on response; monitor levels
Start 20/10 mg daily x 7 days, then increase to 20/10 mg BID

Behavioral and Psychological Symptoms of.contraindications: MAOIs; concurrent quinidine; prolonged QT; complete heart block

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology/Cognitive neurology for diagnosis confirmation, differentiation from AD, and treatment planning
Neuropsychology for formal cognitive testing to characterize executive dysfunction and memory profile
Cardiology for atrial fibrillation management, anticoagulation decisions, and heart failure optimization
Vascular surgery consultation for symptomatic carotid stenosis ≥50% to evaluate for endarterectomy
Physical therapy for gait training, balance assessment, and fall prevention given motor involvement
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment, cognitive strategies, and home safety evaluation
Speech therapy for communication strategies, cognitive-linguistic exercises, and swallowing evaluation if dysphagia
Social work for caregiver support resources, community services, and long-term care planning
Geriatric psychiatry for behavioral symptoms, depression management, and capacity evaluation
Registered dietitian for Mediterranean/DASH diet counseling and sodium restriction education
Smoking cessation program with pharmacotherapy for current smokers
Sleep medicine for obstructive sleep apnea evaluation and CPAP initiation if indicated
Palliative care for advanced vascular dementia symptom management and goals of care discussions

Patient Instructions.item: Call 911 immediately if new stroke symptoms develop (sudden weakness, speech difficulty, vision changes)
Return immediately if sudden worsening of confusion which may indicate new stroke, infection, or delirium
Take all medications as prescribed especially antiplatelet/anticoagulant and statin which prevent further strokes
Complete advance directives (living will, healthcare proxy, POLST) while patient has capacity
Do not drive if cognitive impairment affects judgment or reaction time; formal driving evaluation may be needed
Use pill organizers, alarms, or caregiver supervision to ensure medication adherence
Check blood pressure at home regularly; notify provider if consistently >140/90 or <90/60
Wear medical alert bracelet with diagnosis and emergency contact in case of wandering or emergency
Keep environment safe: remove throw rugs, install grab bars, ensure adequate lighting, secure stove knobs

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Blood pressure target <130/80 mmHg to reduce progression and prevent further strokes (SPRINT-MIND data)
LDL target <70 mg/dL with high-intensity statin for secondary vascular prevention
Smoking cessation immediately; reduces stroke risk by 50% within 1 year of quitting
Mediterranean or MIND diet emphasizing vegetables, berries, fish, whole grains, nuts, and olive oil
Limit sodium to <2300 mg/day (ideally <1500 mg if hypertensive) to improve blood pressure control
Limit alcohol to ≤1 drink daily as excess alcohol increases stroke risk and worsens cognition
Regular aerobic exercise (150 min/week moderate intensity) to improve cardiovascular health and cognition
Treat obstructive sleep apnea with CPAP as OSA worsens vascular risk and cognitive function
Strict glycemic control (HbA1c <7% or individualized 7-8% in frail elderly) to reduce microvascular damage
Social engagement and cognitive stimulation to support cognitive reserve
Weight management with target BMI 18.5-27 kg/m² (less stringent in elderly)
Fall prevention with home safety modifications and assistive devices as needed
CPAP compliance for sleep apnea patients to reduce nocturnal hypoxia and vascular events

differential.features: Insidious onset; gradual decline; memory predominant; no focal signs; no stepwise progression
differential.tests: MRI: hippocampal atrophy without significant WM disease; CSF Aβ42 low, p-tau elevated; amyloid PET positive

differential.features: Features of both; memory impairment with vascular burden
differential.tests: Amyloid PET positive with significant WM disease; CSF biomarkers show AD pattern

differential.features: Visual hallucinations; parkinsonism; REM sleep behavior disorder; fluctuating cognition
differential.tests: DaTscan reduced; clinical criteria; may have less WM disease

differential.features: Personality/behavior changes; disinhibition; apathy; hyperorality; often age <65
differential.tests: FDG-PET frontal hypometabolism; less vascular disease on MRI

differential.features: Triad: gait disturbance (prominent), urinary incontinence, dementia; ventriculomegaly disproportionate to atrophy
differential.tests: MRI: ventriculomegaly with effaced sulci; high-volume LP with gait improvement

differential.features: History of repetitive head trauma; mood and behavioral changes; no diagnostic test in life
differential.tests: History; clinical pattern; cavum septum pellucidum on MRI (suggestive)

differential.features: Migraine with aura; early WM disease; family history; temporal pole and external capsule involvement
differential.tests: NOTCH3 genetic testing; skin biopsy showing GOM deposits

differential.features: Younger age; headache; encephalopathy; multifocal strokes; elevated inflammatory markers
differential.tests: Vessel wall MRI; DSA; brain/leptomeningeal biopsy

differential.features: Rapid progression (weeks-months); myoclonus; periodic sharp waves on EEG; MRI DWI ribboning
Acute change; fluctuating attention; identifiable precipitant (infection, medication, metabolic)
differential.tests: Treat cause; reassess cognition when clear

evidence.recommendation: NINDS-AIREN criteria for vascular dementia diagnosis
Cholinesterase inhibitors for vascular dementia (modest benefit)
Intensive BP lowering reduces dementia risk (SPRINT-MIND)
High-intensity statin for secondary stroke prevention
Antiplatelet therapy for secondary stroke prevention
DOACs preferred over warfarin for AF-related stroke
Physical exercise may slow cognitive decline
Avoid antipsychotics long-term in dementia (mortality risk)
CPAP treatment improves cognition in OSA patients
CSF biomarkers help differentiate VaD from AD
evidence.source: [Skillback et al. Dement Geriatr Cogn Disord 2015](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26448651/)

monitoring.action: Titrate antihypertensives; reduce if symptomatic hypotension
Intensify statin; add ezetimibe or PCSK9 inhibitor

monitoring.frequency: Every 1-2 years or if new symptoms
monitoring.action: Optimize vascular risk factors; investigate new events
PT referral; home safety evaluation; assistive devices
Formal driving evaluation; DMV report if unsafe

disposition.criteria: Stable cognition; no acute stroke; safe environment; adequate caregiver support; outpatient follow-up arranged; reversible causes treated
Acute delirium requiring workup; new stroke symptoms; behavioral crisis unsafe for home; aspiration pneumonia; falls with injury
New stroke with progression; recurrent TIAs; symptomatic carotid stenosis requiring urgent intervention
Severe behavioral disturbance requiring specialized psychiatric management; danger to self or others
Progressive decline; caregiver unable to manage safely; wandering; 24-hour supervision needed
End-stage vascular dementia; recurrent aspiration; weight loss; goals focused on comfort
Neurology every 3-6 months initially; every 6-12 months when stable; PCP for vascular risk factor management
